Detailed Description

This is the superclass for classes which provide basic support for animations which can be started, ended, and have IAnimatorListeners added to them. 

 Animator *animator = new ObjectAnimator::ofFloatN(myObject, "x", 2, 0.0f, 100.0f);

 animator->setsetDuration(500);
 animator->start();

 delete animator;

Definition at line 30 of file Animator.h.

Member Function Documentation

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::addListener ( IAnimatorListener *  listener) [virtual]

Adds a listener to the set of listeners that are sent events through the life of an animation, such as start, repeat, and end.

Parameters:
listenerthe listener to be added to the current set of listeners for this animation.
virtual void gaia::core::Animator::cancel ( ) [virtual]

Cancels the animation.

Unlike end(), cancel() causes the animation to stop in its tracks, sending an gaia::core::IAnimatorListener::onAnimationCancel(Animator*) to its listeners, followed by an gaia::core::IAnimatorListener::onAnimationEnd(Animator*) message.

This method must be called on the thread that is running the animation.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::end ( ) [virtual]

Ends the animation.

This causes the animation to assign the end value of the property being animated, then calling the IAnimatorListener::onAnimationEnd(Animator*)} method on its listeners.

This method must be called on the thread that is running the animation.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

the number of milliseconds to delay running the animation

virtual bool gaia::core::Animator::isRunning ( ) [pure virtual]

Returns whether this Animator is currently running (having been started and gone past any initial startDelay period and not yet ended).

Returns:
Whether the Animator is running.

Implemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual bool gaia::core::Animator::isStarted ( ) [virtual]

Returns whether this Animator has been started and not yet ended.

This state is a superset of the state of isRunning(), because an Animator with a nonzero getStartDelay() startDelay will return true for isStarted() during the delay phase, whereas isRunning() will return true only after the delay phase is complete.

Returns:
Whether the Animator has been started and not yet ended.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::removeAllListeners ( ) [virtual]

Removes all listeners from this object.

This is equivalent to calling getListeners() followed by calling clear() on the returned list of listeners.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::setInterpolator ( ITimeInterpolator *  value) [pure virtual]

The time interpolator used in calculating the elapsed fraction of this animation.

The interpolator determines whether the animation runs with linear or non-linear motion, such as acceleration and deceleration. The default value is AccelerateDecelerateInterpolator

Parameters:
valuethe interpolator to be used by this animation

Implemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::setTarget ( PropertyAnimatable *  target) [virtual]

Sets the target object whose property will be animated by this animation.

Not all subclasses operate on target objects (for example, ValueAnimator, but this method is on the superclass for the convenience of dealing generically with those subclasses that do handle targets.

Parameters:
targetThe object being animated

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::setupEndValues ( ) [virtual]

This method tells the object to use appropriate information to extract ending values for the animation.

For example, a AnimatorSet object will pass this call to its child objects to tell them to set up the values. A ObjectAnimator object will use the information it has about its target object and PropertyValuesHolder objects to get the start values for its properties. An ValueAnimator object will ignore the request since it does not have enough information (such as a target object) to gather these values.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::setupStartValues ( ) [virtual]

This method tells the object to use appropriate information to extract starting values for the animation.

For example, a AnimatorSet object will pass this call to its child objects to tell them to set up the values. A ObjectAnimator object will use the information it has about its target object and PropertyValuesHolder objects to get the start values for its properties. An ValueAnimator object will ignore the request since it does not have enough information (such as a target object) to gather these values.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator, and gaia::core::AnimatorSet.

virtual void gaia::core::Animator::start ( ) [virtual]

Starts this animation.

If the animation has a nonzero startDelay, the animation will start running after that delay elapses. A non-delayed animation will have its initial value(s) set immediately, followed by calls to IAnimatorListener::onAnimationStart(Animator*) for any listeners of this animator.

The animation started by calling this method will be run on the thread that called this method. This thread should have a Looper on it (a runtime exception will be thrown if this is not the case). Also, if the animation will animate properties of objects in the view hierarchy, then the calling thread should be the UI thread for that view hierarchy.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ValueAnimator, gaia::core::AnimatorSet, and gaia::core::ObjectAnimator.
